title: Ordering Pizza Is Not That Easy

Ordering Pizza Is Not That Easy

Always Not Quite
Apr 1

Our best birthday parties were with family. Inviting our western school friends over for a classic birthday bash was always complicated because 1) they would never take their shoes off at the door, 2) explaining why we wore a shirt and pants (a.k.a. our burkinis) in the swimming pool got old real fast, 3) we didn’t really have any friends.

My maman would bake us her special vanilla cake with layers of rosewater whip cream and halal raspberry jello. My baba, being an artist would use icing to draw a marvelous happy birthday design on the surface of the cake, along with some big smiley clowns, flowers, or sunshine. And every year, every birthday, they would pretend we didn’t know a cake was made, the lights would go off, candles would be lit, and we’d look surprised.

This grand entry was always flawlessly synchronized with the most famous Persian song, Tavalod by Andy. He is undoubtedly the King of all Persian Pop. The Ricky Martin of Persia. The Celine Dion of your childhood. And he also should have retired 15 years ago. This song would go on repeat and a mega dance party of three would commence. Baba would sit at the table sipping his tea, taking discreet gazes at maman, telling us how beautiful she looked. “A supermodel!” Given that it was my birthday, I would have preferred that the spotlight be on me….But we stood no chance with baba being the judge.

One year, we asked our parents if we could order in pizza and watch a movie. Something easy, fun, cozy, and very American, for a change. “Of course azizam, no big deal! Afterall, we are living in their country,” he said. But really, it was a BIG deal. Ordering Pizza for us was NEVER easy.

You may be thinking, what’s this obsession with the pizza cutter?! See pizza shops in the U.S.A also serve pepperoni. That’s pork. They cut pepperoni pizzas with a pizza cutter….the same pizza cutter they use on other pizzas. Here’s what happens:

You think you ordered a vegetarian pizza but really……

We needed to make sure our pizza was NOT contaminated with pork.

This made ordering pizza VERY complicated and the phone orders would be long and drawn out. So we tried to get our message across in various ways, hoping that ONE would easily stick. Here are the methods we’ve tried and tested:

1. Be honest, explain the WHY. Educate the pizza guy. Surely, they’ll understand.

Ok, scratch that. Don’t say the word “Muslim”. You’ll lose them completely.

2. Claim strict vegetarianism. That’s more Western.

….we knew he probably forgot or didn’t bother to change the knife. So for precautionary sake….we cut off all the edges.

3. Try to avoid the WHOLE thing:

We miss Iran every time we have Pizza in America. Our family, our friends, the simplicity of ordering halal Pizza straight to your door….

But, I had a great birthday after all. And we ate pizza….eventually.

Note: We can tell you from experience that it is NOT easy cutting your own pizza. Nor is it easy ordering it.

Thanks for reading! Make sure to follow The Junction!

Always Not Quite is a graphic memoir written and illustrated by two sisters about their experiences as not-quite Iranians, not-quite Americans, and not-quite Muslims. We like to mix truth with funnies. If you like this piece, check out some others below:

It Wasn’t an Honest Mistake
But most people will keep telling me it is.medium.com
It’s Hard to Say Goodbye
Short. Simple. Direct. Purposeful. Clear.blog.usejournal.com
Where there is an emergency, there is tea.
Persians can be very ethnocentric when it comes to one thing.medium.com
Immigrants Are Santa’s Worst Enemy
Everything we learned about Christmas, we learned from Hollywoodmedium.com
Thanks to Stephen M. Tomic.
